contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Iced ship1.jpg|250px|right|thumb|Ice coating a [[United States Navy]] vessel]] '''Icing''' on [[ship]]s is a serious hazard where cold [[temperature]]s (below about -10Â°C) combined with high [[wind speed]] (typically force 8 or above on the [[Beaufort scale]]) result in spray blown off the [[sea]] freezing immediately on contact with the ship. If not frequently knocked off, the [[ice]] can soon build up on the ship's superstructure to a sufficient weight to cause the ship to [[capsize]]. It is typically a problem in [[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]] seas, but can also occur in other seas such as the [[Gulf of Saint Lawrence]], the [[Sea of Japan]], the [[Baltic Sea]], and very rarely, the [[North Sea]]. ==See also== *[[Shipping Forecast]] ==External links== *[http://www.crrel.usace.army.mil/aviation_icing/ US Army Engineer Research] [[Category:Nautical terms]]
